Column Comment.0: SUPPORT FACILITY SUBTYPE: The type of support facility that is described by thisrow of data. These values are managed by check constraint, and may only be thename of a valid sub type of support facility.
Column Comment.1: RIG IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier assigned to the rig. Rigs may be drilling rigs orother kinds of service rigs assigned to a well site.
Column Comment.2: BLOWOUT PREVENTER IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the component of theblowout preventor.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ANNULAR COUNT: the number of annular BOP. These are usually rubberdiaphrams or bags that are used to seal the system off in the event of a reversepressure.
Column Comment.5: BLOW OUT PREVENTOR COUNT: the number of blow out preventorsof this type,described in this row of data, on the rig.
Column Comment.6: BLOWOUT PREVENTOR DIAMETER: the diameter of the blowout preventor.
Column Comment.8: BLOWOUT PREVENTER NACE CERTIFICATION INDICATOR; A Y/N indicator thatthe BOP has been certified by NACE (www.nace.org)
Column Comment.9: BOP POSITION DESCRIPTION: Desctiption of the position of the BOP on the rig.
Column Comment.10: BLOWOUT PREVENTER PRESSURE RATING: The pressure rating for the BOP.
Column Comment.12: BLOWOUT PREVENTOR TYPE: A large valve at the top of a well that may beclosed if the drilling crew loses control of formation fluids. By closing this valve(usually operated remotely via hydraulic actuators), the drilling crew usually regainscontrol of the reservoir, and procedures can then be initiated to increase the muddensity until it is possible to open the BOP and retain pressure control of theformation. BOPs come in a variety of styles, sizes and pressure ratings. Some caneffectively close over an open wellbore, some are designed to seal around tubularcomponents in the well (drillpipe, casing or tubing) and others are fitted withhardened steel shearing surfaces that can actually cut through drillpipe. Since BOPsare critically important to the safety of the crew, the rig and the wellbore itself, BOPsare inspected, tested and refurbished at regular intervals determined by acombination of risk assessment, local practice, well type and legal requirements.BOP tests vary from daily function testing on critical wells to monthly or less frequenttesting on wells thought to have low probability of well control problems.(Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary). Usual values include single, double, shear, ram,diverter, gate, single gate etc. .
Column Comment.13: CAPACITY: the capacity of the equipment.
Column Comment.15: EQUIPMENT CATALOGUE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the list of kinds ofequipment. Think of this as a catalogue or brochure that shows all the kinds ofequipment that you may use, but may or may not actually have. Actual peices ofequipment that exist are defined in the table EQUIPMENT. Use this table to definethe make and model number of a piece of equipment without identifying the specificpiece of equipment.
Column Comment.16: DOUBLE COUNT: The number of double ram, annulus or shear devices on the BOP.
Column Comment.17: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.18: EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a specific peice of equipment.
Column Comment.19: EXPIRY DATE: Date on which the data in this row of data was no longer in effect.
Column Comment.20: INPUT TYPE: The type of input into an electrical device. Usually measured in Watts.
Column Comment.21: INSTALL DATE: the date this piece of equipment was installed on the rig.
Column Comment.22: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.23: REFERENCE NUMBER: Reference number for the BOP.
Column Comment.24: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.25: REMOVE DATE: The date that this piece of equipment was removed from the rig.
Column Comment.26: SINGLE COUNT: The number of single ram, annular or shear devices on the BOP.
Column Comment.27: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.28: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.29: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.30: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.31: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.32: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.33: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.34: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
